[[Efficiency Decoration]] | relations = [[Roger Hay]] (brother) | laterwork = }} Major '''Hugh Allport Hay''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MC|ED}} (24 November 1889 – 13 October 1965) was a British [[World War I]] [[flying ace]] credited with five aerial victories.{{cite web |url=http://www.theaerodrome.com/aces/england/hay1.php |title=Hugh Allport Hay |work=The Aerodrome |year=2015 |accessdate=20 March 2015 }} ==Biography== ===Family background and education=== He was the eldest of three sons born to [[The Reverend]] Reynell Wreford Hay and his wife Margaret Alice (née Bolton). His grandfather William Hay was a merchant and ship owner from [[Bishopwearmouth]],{{cite web |url= http://www.lan-opc.org.uk/Rossendale/Newchurch/stnicholas/marriages_1884-1914.html |title=Marriages at St Nicholas in the Parish of Newchurch in Rossendale, Lancashire (1884-1914) |work=Lancashire OnLine Parish Clerk Project |year=2012 |accessdate=20 March 2015}} while his uncle, William Delisle Hay, was a novelist and [[mycologist]].{{cite web |url= http://www.victorianresearch.org/atcl/show_author.php?aid=2761 |title=William Delisle Hay |first=Troy J. |last=Bassett |work=At the Circulating Library: A Database of Victorian Fiction 1837-1901 |year=2015 |accessdate=20 March 2015}} At the time of his birth his father was teaching at [[Newchurch, Lancashire|Newchurch]] Grammar School, Lancashire,{{cite web |url= http://www.lan-opc.org.uk/Rossendale/Newchurch/stnicholas/baptisms_1890-1904.html |title=Baptisms at St Nicholas in the Parish of Newchurch in Rossendale |work=Lancashire OnLine Parish Clerk Project |year=2015 |accessdate=20 March 2015}} but in 1892 was appointed the [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] of [[Lea, Wiltshire|Garsdon and Lea]] in [[Wiltshire]].{{cite web |url= http://specialcollections.le.ac.uk/utils/getfile/collection/p16445coll4/id/339948/filename/351293.pdfpage/page/129 |title=Kelly's Directory of Wiltshire |page=110 |year=1907 |edition=12th |accessdate=20 March 2015}} He was educated at [[Armstrong College, Newcastle]] (then part of [[Durham University]], now part of [[Newcastle University]]). ===World War I=== After serving as a cadet in the [[Officers' Training Corps]], on 27 January 1915 Hay was commissioned as a second lieutenant (on probation) in the 3rd Battalion, [[West Yorkshire Regiment]], alongside his brothers Guy Baldwin Hay (1890–1951{{London Gazette |date=1 April 1952 |issue=39505 |startpage=1871 |nolink=yes}}) and [[Roger Hay|Roger Bolton Hay]] (1895–1917).{{London Gazette |date=26 January 1915 |issue=29050 |startpage=806 |endpage=807 |nolink=yes}} On 2 February 1916 he was appointed a temporary supernumerary lieutenant,{{London Gazette |date=14 March 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29511 |startpage=2920 |nolink=yes}} and on 24 June, while attached to the 1st Battalion of the West Yorkshires, was awarded the [[Military Cross]].{{London Gazette |date=23 June 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29637 |startpage=6305 |endpage=6306 |nolink=yes}} His citation read: :2nd Lieutenant Hugh Allport Hay, Special Reserve, West Yorkshire Regiment (attd. 1st Bn.). ::For gallantry and ability. He made a very close reconnaissance of enemy trenches prior to attack, and in the attack itself led his platoon with great ability. He has served for many months in the front line, and has proved himself a capable leader.{{London Gazette |date=25 July 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29684 |startpage=7437 |nolink=yes}} He relinquished his temporary rank on 4 July,{{London Gazette |date=24 November 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29839 |startpage=11578 |nolink=yes}} but was promoted to full lieutenant on 26 September.{{London Gazette |date=31 October 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29811 |startpage=10623 |nolink=yes}} In mid-1917 Hay was seconded to the [[Royal Flying Corps]], receiving Royal Aero Club Aviator's Certificate No. 5481 and being appointed a flying officer on 29 November.{{London Gazette |date=21 December 1917 |supp=yes |issue=30443 |startpage=13428 |nolink=yes}} Hay was posted to [[No. 11 Squadron RFC]] in early 1918 to fly the [[Bristol F.2 Fighter]].Shores ''et.al.'' (1990), pp.188–189. On 1 April, the Army's Royal Flying Corps (RFC) and the Royal Naval Air Service (RNAS) were merged to form the Royal Air Force, and a week later, on the 7th, Hay gained his first victory when he and observer/gunner Sergeant P. A. Sherlock drove down an Albatros C 'out of control' over [[Grévillers]]. On 4 May he and Sherlock shot a [[Pfalz D.III]] down in flames over [[Marquion]], and on 11 August, with 2nd Lieutenant E. J. Norris, he did the same to an [[Albatros D.V]] south of [[Péronne, Somme|Péronne]]. On 26 August Hay was appointed a temporary captain while serving as a [[flight commander]],{{London Gazette |date=3 September 1918 |issue=30881 |startpage=10395 |nolink=yes}} and on 6 September, Hay and Lieutenant A. H. Craig destroyed and drove down two [[Fokker D.VII]]s west of [[Cambrai]]. Hay left the RAF after the war, being transferred to the unemployed list on 2 June 1919.{{London Gazette |date=24 June 1919 |issue=31416 |startpage=7944 |endpage=7945 |nolink=yes}} ===World War II=== Hay returned to military service just prior to World War II, serving in an [[Anti-Aircraft Command|anti-aircraft unit]] of the [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|Territorial Army]]. He was commissioned as a captain, and appointed administration officer of the 1/5th Battalion, [[Durham Light Infantry]], on 23 March 1939.{{London Gazette |date=16 May 1939 |issue=34626 |startpage=3299 |nolink=yes}} Hay relinquished his post of administration officer on 2 September,{{London Gazette |date=2 July 1940 |supp=yes |issue=34888 |startpage=4090 |nolink=yes}} and on 1 August 1940 his unit was transferred and renamed, becoming the 54th Searchlight Regiment, [[Royal Artillery]].{{London Gazette |date=27 August 1940 |supp=yes |issue=34934 |startpage=5281 |nolink=yes}}{{cite web |url= http://heritage.stockton.gov.uk/organisations/5th-battalion-durham-light-infantry/ |title=5th Battalion, Durham Light Infantry|work=Stockton Heritage |year=2015 |accessdate=20 March 2015}} He served throughout the war, finally relinquishing his commission, having exceeded the age limit, on 22 August 1945, and was granted the [[honorary rank]] of major.{{London Gazette |date=4 September 1945 |supp=yes |issue=37254 |startpage=4475 |nolink=yes}} On 13 April 1951 he was awarded the [[Efficiency Decoration]].{{London Gazette |date=10 April 1951 |supp=yes |issue=39200 |startpage=2062
